There was a woman that was pregnent. Some crazy guy attacked her, and killed her. The womb was cut open with a baby inside, still alive. it was taken out by the man and killed. The man was accused of two muders. If he had simply put the baby back in the womb, then killed her, he would only have been accused of one murder.

This parallels the Scott Peterson case somewhat. He was convicted of two murders for killing his wife and their unborn child.
 
 (I guess that fetus was considered a person.)

This parallels the Scott Peterson case somewhat. He was convicted of two murders for killing his wife and their unborn child.
 
 (I guess that fetus was considered a person.)

 
 That's what bothers me so much about the pro-choice position on personhood regarding a fetus: there is an obvious double-standard. They seem to have no problem with the idea of it being a person when a murderer is convicted of two murders in case of killing a pregnant woman, but they refuse to allow for personhood with the fetus when it comes to the abortion issue. At least they could be consistent.

The alternative bill that I mentioned had a provision into the 10th amendment to affect state laws.
 
 The UVVA was nothing more than a try by pro-lifers to create a stepping stone to a national ban, it would have done little to nothing to help pregnant women. 
 
 Making a separate victim is idiotic. Increasing the sentencing for crimes against the woman would be much more effective.

...Making a separate victim is idiotic. Increasing the sentencing for crimes against the woman would be much more effective.
Increasing the sentences would only add to the already horrendous problem of prison overcrowding.

 Carrying out the death penalty is the only true deterrent to repeated crimes against anybody.

 
 This isn't the forum to really discuss if the death penalty is appropriate for a certain crime.
 
 We aren't talking about repeated crimes against anyone, we are talking about violence against pregnant women repeated or not.

Does that mean that the fetus is considered a person before birth?
 
 I've seen a definition of "fetus" as a developing vertibrate lifeform, especially as in humans three months after conception up until birth. When is a human fetus considered to be a person?

 
 Excellent point Jim and the reason why it is considered a "slippery slope" by some pro-choicers. I think it common sense to consider aborting on the day before the "baby" would have been born to be murder. I also think it common sense to consider the destruction of a fertilized egg or a small assemblage of human cells not to be murder.

Then address my first statement...that prison overcrowding would be increased, with possibly little or no decrease in crimes against women.

 
 Prison overcrowding is also outside the scope of the debate. Why do you think there will be little to no decrease in crimes with a law that increases penalties for crimes against pregnant women instead of a separate offense?

I think it common sense to consider aborting on the day before the "baby" would have been born to be murder. I also think it common sense to consider the destruction of a fertilized egg or a small assemblage of human cells not to be murder.

 
 Agreed. That's why the debate is generally an all or nothing thing. Any point besides birth is really arbitrary, so it's hard to justify "abortion allowed this day, but not the day after". Then both sides will always want to push it "just one more day or week" either one direction or the other.

Prison overcrowding is also outside the scope of the debate. 
...until the mention of increased prison time as a proposed deterrent.
 
 
 Why do you think there will be little to no decrease in crimes with a law that increases penalties for crimes against pregnant women instead of a separate offense?
Penalties don't usually scare criminals. Even the crimes that carry the death penalty are committed on an ever increasing scale. You'd think that the threat of death would stop someone from committing such a crime, but it doesn't. Do you actually think that a criminal will think, "Gee, it used to be only 18 months for this crime, now it's 36...I'd better not do it."? Or will he say,"This one's pregnant, so I'd better pick another victim."?
 
 Won't happen.
 
 True, longer sentences might keep a particular criminal off the streets for a longer time, but prison overcrowding would only drive the early release of other criminals to take his place.

...until the mention of increased prison time as a proposed deterrent.

 
 Even with the mention, we aren't discussing what punishment is appropriate for the offender, merely what will help pregnant women.
 
 

 Penalties don't usually scare criminals.

 
 Then what's the point of penalties? ;)
 
 

 Even the crimes that carry the death penalty are committed on an ever increasing scale. You'd think that the threat of death would stop someone from committing such a crime, but it doesn't. Do you actually think that a criminal will think, "Gee, it used to be only 18 months for this crime, now it's 36...I'd better not do it."? Or will he say,"This one's pregnant, so I'd better pick another victim."?

... Given that violence against pregnant women is a problem, what would you suggest? Besides death, since death doesn't seem to be a deterrent and deterrence is our goal here.

 Violence against innocents is not necessary, be they human or animal.
 Violence against women in general is reprehensible. Violence against pregnant women is even more so.
 Violence against criminals is quite easily justified depending on the nature of the crime.
 
 The only way to completely stop crime is to get rid of the criminals. Unfortunately, criminals are born daily. It's hard to understand why the Pro-Choice, abortion-happy, fetus-killing life takers can't seem to agree that violent criminals should die.
 
 Scott Peterson should be dead already.

Oh, but death is a deterrent. It's you preferred deterrent to birth.

 Other than assigning a bodyguard to each pregnant woman (laugh loudly) or locking up all the pregnant women (laugh louder), there's not much you can do besides reduce the number of criminals. The most effective way to do this is to KILL THEM! (don't laugh)

 The only way to completely stop crime is to get rid of the criminals. Unfortunately, criminals are born daily. It's hard to understand why the Pro-Choice, abortion-happy, fetus-killing life takers can't seem to agree that violent criminals should die.

 One would think that if your answer to criminals is to KILL THEM, you would welcome low income women having abortions, since criminal activity is directly related to poverty.
 
 I have no problem with the death penalty in theory. If it does not provide a deterrance and is more expensive than simply jailing them then I do not see the point. I also maintain that a civilized society does not just line them up and shoot them. I believe in the Constitution's goals of fair trials and, despite the crime, that cruel punishment is not something we as a society should do.
 
 

 Scott Peterson should be dead already.

 Contradictory there? Perhaps. There is a difference sometimes between what I feel on a gut level and how I think society should behave.

I believe I said it is the most effective, not the most efficient.
 
 
 

 ...
 
 One would think that if your answer to criminals is to KILL THEM, you would welcome low income women having abortions, since criminal activity is directly related to poverty.
 False logic. Guilt by association and probability of future criminal activity are not valid reasons to punish people. I don't know how the poverty level affects crimes against pregnant women anyway. It may have less affect on that type crime than it does on theft and burglary.
 
 I'm not one for punishing people just because they are poor.
 
 
 

 I have no problem with the death penalty in theory. If it does not provide a deterrance and is more expensive than simply jailing them then I do not see the point. I also maintain that a civilized society does not just line them up and shoot them. I believe in the Constitution's goals of fair trials and, despite the crime, that cruel punishment is not something we as a society should do.
I realize we're off topic again, but you do need addressing. Death is the ultimate deterrent. Our system is only more expensive because the penalty is delayed through years and years of appeals. Judge Roy Bean had the right idea...if you're found guilty by twelve, you're dead by six.
 
 I don't believe we should line them up for shooting, either. However, a deep sea fishing trip with the criminals cut up for bait would be a fun outing, especially if we catch some trophy fish. The criminals that don't become bait can be just plain ole fish food. No burial costs and Good Will can have all their clothes.

You will not find absolute proof of guilt in most cases. Even if you had a video of the act, you'd wonder if the video was concocted. Given enough time and equipment, one could produce a video of anybody doing anything.
 
 
 

 Contradictory there? Perhaps. There is a difference sometimes between what I feel on a gut level and how I think society should behave.
Let not your heart be troubled...most of us homosapiens are that way.
Yeah um, you shouldn't kill criminals. Thats all I really have to say.

 I find it funny how a person can see how wrong it is to kill a baby after cutting it from a womb, yet they don't think it's wrong while the baby is still in it.
 That's what baffles me about Pro-choicers(Pro-abortionist). I wonder if there were a glass window allowing people to see what they are killing, if they would still feel no emotion.

Agreed. That's why the debate is generally an all or nothing thing. Any point besides birth is really arbitrary, so it's hard to justify "abortion allowed this day, but not the day after". Then both sides will always want to push it "just one more day or week" either one direction or the other.

 I agree that a definition of personhood would be contentious since, as you say, you could push abortion just one day more or less. But, if we can agree on at least the most basic definitions of personhood, such as the fetus having a rudimentary mind or sensing pain, then science can at least give us some lower limits about when the brain is developed enough to sustain a mind or feel pain - thus defining the earliest possibilities of personhood. My understanding so far is that this limit is roughly at the beginning of the third trimester, when sufficient neural connections have been made. 
 
 Yes, there is no clear line to the beginning of personhood and, even if there were, it would vary from fetus to fetus. However, do you really think that the current state of affairs in the debate on abortion is better?!?!? Now, pro-choice people are faced with the possibility of all abortions being outlawed while pro-life people are faced with the possibility of fetus's getting aborted one day from birth. I would much prefer having the debate focus on the fuzzy line of personhood, plus or minus a few weeks, than what we currently have.

Giving people death penality doesn't really decrease criminal overcrowding in prisons anyway. Very few, nation wide, are killed. There will still be a problem with "overcrowding" as you put it.
 
 
 It has also been shown there is no evidence that Execution acts any more on behalf of society in terms of deterrant than does life in prison. In fact, there are many areas in which death penality is enacted that have higher crime rates than where it isn't allowed.
 
 You cannot equate killing someone to deterrant. It's prevention of repeat offense, but this can be accomplished through other means. According to ethics, it's "elimination and prevention of repeat offences," it is, but that's not considered deterrant effect.
 
 Death Penality isn't and wouldn't be a deterrant anyway due to the psychological state of many people who commit violent crimes. Many are crimes of passion or sociopathic. T hey don't care what the consequences are.
 
 You are falsely ascribing traits of rational humans to irrational humans, which is the primary fault of your argument here concerning deterrance.
 
 
 I realize we're off topic again, but you do need addressing. Death is the ultimate deterrent. 

 
 This isn't true, and you have no studies that are credible to show they are. Studies are largely showing they are about the same, and in many areas with death penality, violent crime increases, even when people are executed. See above about the mentality of the criminal. It's not the Kantian rational ivory tower version you think it is.
 
 

 Our system is only more expensive because the penalty is delayed through years and years of appeals. 

 
 Appeals are necessary since hundreds of people were exhonerated and moratoriums were enacted.
 
 

 Judge Roy Bean had the right idea...if you're found guilty by twelve, you're dead by six.

 
 That judge is silly.
 
 

 I don't believe we should line them up for shooting, either. However, a deep sea fishing trip with the criminals cut up for bait would be a fun outing, especially if we catch some trophy fish. 

 
 Oh yes, because that silly statement is so moral. Revenge and lex talionis are hardly moral principles.
 
 

 The criminals that don't become bait can be just plain ole fish food. No burial costs and Good Will can have all their clothes.
 

 
 You can't just go cutting up people and using them as fishfood. It's sick, but you aren't suprising me here.
 
 
 
 I wonder if there were a glass window allowing people to see what they are killing, if they would still feel no emotion.

 
 So you think it's wrong to kill something by virtue of being alive and Human? I disagree. It depends on its level of development.

I find it funny how a person can see how wrong it is to kill a baby after cutting it from a womb, yet they don't think it's wrong while the baby is still in it.
 That's what baffles me about Pro-choicers(Pro-abortionist). I wonder if there were a glass window allowing people to see what they are killing, if they would still feel no emotion.

 
 Why do you think they feel no emotion? All the women I know who have aborted did so under very difficult circumstances and it was horrible for them.
 
 Most women who seek abortion are not unfeeling sluts. They are real women, with real issues, and real circumstances that lead them to that choice. Want to help those babies? Address the issues the women face and don't demonize. No amount of legislation can make for succesful pregnancy without the support of the mother. Dismiss her and you will fail to do anything to help anyone.

Foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of a sick mind! ;)

 
 Not to be picky, just let you know, that quote is "hobgoblin of little  minds"

Not to be picky, just let you know, that quote is "hobgoblin of little  minds"
